claim: In the U.S., you cannot be prosecuted for a crime if the police allow you to commit it and could have stopped you.

supporting.text: Entrapment is a legal defense in the U.S. that prevents prosecution if law enforcement induces someone to commit a crime they would not have otherwise committed.

attacks.text: Entrapment is a legal defense in the U.S. that prevents prosecution if law enforcement induces someone to commit a crime they would not have otherwise committed.
Entrapment only applies if the defendant can prove they had no predisposition to commit the crime before government involvement.
Many courts require clear evidence of coercion or excessive pressure by law enforcement to establish entrapment.
Predisposition can be inferred from prior criminal behavior or expressed willingness to commit similar offenses.
Undercover operations are generally lawful unless they involve extreme inducements that create new criminal intent.

supporting.text: The Supreme Court has ruled that entrapment occurs when government agents persuade or coerce an individual into committing a crime they had no predisposition to commit.

attacks.text: The Supreme Court has ruled that entrapment occurs when government agents persuade or coerce an individual into committing a crime they had no predisposition to commit.

The legal standard for predisposition focuses on the defendant's state of mind before government involvement.
Supreme Court precedents require examining both government conduct and defendant predisposition, not just opportunity.

Legal precedent shows that mere inaction by police does not automatically invalidate a prosecution unless due process rights are violated.

attacks.text: If law enforcement actively facilitates a crime without justification, courts may dismiss charges due to violations of due process.
